awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Future of Search: User, Social Networks and Language
awd_abstract_narration:
How to retrieve relevant information for a specific user under a specific set of circumstances is a challenging research problem. The goal of this research project is to tackle this challenge and lay the foundation for the next generation of search engines. Instead of simply matching a query to documents that contain query words, the approach developed here is a unified user-centric retrieval framework that consists of: (1) personalization: learning a user model that takes into consideration the content, context and decision criteria of a user; (2) language processing: learning better text representation for retrieval from heterogeneous corpus and linguistic resources; and (3) social networks: further improving the user model based on social norms and a user's social networks.  To evaluate the framework, a personalized social search engine will be developed. 

The result of this project will be a unified retrieval framework with a set of novel techniques applicable across a wide range of information retrieval (IR) tasks, including: search engines, recommender systems and adaptive filtering systems.  Through the PI's industry collaboration, the results of this project are expected to be incorporated in commercial systems, and thus benefit millions of users. 

K-12 students, undergraduate, graduate students, and engineers in Silicon Valley will be involved and benefit from the project. The project will lead to research-based educational materials (lecture slides, video lectures, book chapters and course projects). Project results, including publications, open source software, annotated data sets, demos and course materials, will be disseminated via the project website (http://www.soe.ucsc.edu/~yiz/futureofsearch).

por.por_cntn:
This project developed foundations for the next generation of search engines. We We introduced Probabilistic Latent Relational Modeling approach (PLRM) and its variations for personalized search and recommendation. Based on that, we developed techniques for learning personalized user model that takes into consideration the content, context and decision criteria of a user. We also developed better techniques to learn the hidden representations of languges from heterogeneous text and user behavior data. We demonstrated how the proposed techniques can benefit search ranking,recommendation ranking and support users' decision making when using the search/recommendation system. We also introduced economics metrics such as marginal utility, multiple products utility and social surplus as objective functions for personalized recommendation systems, and demonstrated the effects on various applications such as e-commerce and job recommendation. 

The proposed project has advanced the state of the art in information retrieval (IR) and personalized recommendation systems through the development of those new technologies. Those technilogies have been published in top tier conferences in the field, such as ACM SIGIR, WWW conference, ACM Recommendation Systems Conference, ACM CIKM and WSDM.

The project has benefit hundreds of millions of users through the PI’s industry collaborations. The project has lead to research-based educational materials (open source software, lectures and projects). It has helped educate the new generation of IT undergraduate and graduate students, and has provided post graduate education for engineers in nearby Silicon Valley through the PI’s courses offered at UCSC Silicon Valley center. The project has helped K-12 students vocabulary learning through the PI’s project sponsored by the U.S. Department of Education and has helped fighting bullying activities in social media in many K-12 schools through the PI’s industry collaborations.
